public DeferredEventManager deferredEvents

runThread

public java.lang.Thread runThread
this is the thtead executing the viewerRun method. Since the basic model requires that everything happens in this thread, code where you suspect "leakage" in to other processes can check.

See Also:
ViewerRun(int)

lockAndLoadImages

public void lockAndLoadImages()
preload static images. This had better have only minimal dependency on the real environment, because we only load the root and sharedinfo. This loads static variables, and may be invoked by a class preloader, or by the startup of the actual class, so we been to be careful to synchronize through a static variable

StartDragging

public abstract void StartDragging(HitPoint hp)
StartDragging is called from the default version of MouseMotion(int, int, lib.MouseState) when the mouse button is down and the mouse moves, or when the mouse button is released (possibly without being moved). The intended interface for your canvas to use StartDragging to trigger events which involve picking up and moving an object.

MouseMotion

public HitPoint MouseMotion(int eventX,
                            int eventY,
                            MouseState upcode)
This is called from the viewer event loop when there is any mouse activity that needs to be handled. The mechanics guarantee that every "down" will be matches by an "up", and every down or up will be followed by a "move".

ViewerRun

public void ViewerRun(int waitTime)
this is the run loop for the window. All significant events should occur here. Actions due to network, mouse, or keyboard should be deferred and handled here. Canvas painting is also deferred and handles here.

About the only thing that doesn't happen here is activity by robots to search for next moves.

Specified by:
ViewerRun in interface CanvasProtocol

drawImage

public java.awt.Rectangle drawImage(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                                    java.awt.Image im,
                                    double[] scale,
                                    int x,
                                    int y,
                                    double boxw,
                                    double xscale,
                                    double jitter,
                                    java.lang.String text,
                                    boolean artCenterText)
this is the primary method to draw an images with transparent backgrounds on a canvas. The images are clipped to a slightly smaller box to avoid the "edge garbage" bug.

Another feature of this interface is that the images are displayed quickly at first, then "slow scaled" to the desired size.

Parameters:
gc - the graphics context
im - the image to draw
scale - the x,y offset and scale factor to expand or shrink the image
x - the x coordinate to draw at
y - the y coordinate to draw at
boxw - the box width to draw
xscale - separate x scale for nonuniform scaling on the x axis
jitter - percentage of size to jitter the image position
text - text to draw over the image
artCenterText - if true center the text in the box, otherwise at the art center
Returns:
returns the actual rectangle where the image was drawn

getAltChipset

public int getAltChipset()
This is the key method for defining alternate sets of artwork based on the DrawableImage class. At a very low level, just before the canvas draws an image based on DrawableImage, it calls getAltChip. These two methods work together to make appropriate substututions in the artwork.

The meaning of the alternate chip index, and the nature of the substitutions made, are a matter of agreement between your canvas and chip classes.

Returns:
a chipset index (default 0)
See Also:
getAltChip

addSprite

public void addSprite(SpriteProtocol ss)
add a new sprite to the active list. All the added sprites are activated at the same time, so a start time of 0 will be the same for all sprites. Sprites are drawn in reverse order that they were added to the list, so the first sprite added will be drawn last.

Parameters:
ss -
